[$BOX] [$CELL] [$BLOCK]

Causes of Airway Obstruction

A distinction is made between partial and complete airway obstruction. Obstructions can occur at any level of the airway from the nose and mouth to an area deep in the trachea.

In the unconscious patient, the soft palate and epiglottis are the most common sites of obstruction. Obstruction may be the result of vomit, blood, or foreign bodies. Irritation of the upper airway may result in laryngeal spasm. Laryngeal obstruction can be caused by edema due to burning, inflammation or anaphylaxis.

Obstruction of the respiratory tract below the level of the larynx is less likely but can occur in cases of excessive bronchial secretions, mucosal edema, bronchospasm, pulmonary edema, and aspiration of gastric contents.

[$/BLOCK] [$/CELL] [$/BOX]
Content.Name: Causes of Airway Obstruction
